note: Biblical majuscule | Similar to Vindob. theol. gr. 31, Paris. suppl. gr. 1286, and Codex Purpureus Rossanensis, suggesting a date in the sixth century (501-600 CE) and a place of origin in the region of Syria or Antioch (cf. G. Cavallo, Ricerche sulla maiuscola biblica (Florence, 1967), pp. 98-104; P. Orsini, Manoscritti in maiuscola biblica. Materiali per un aggiornamento (Cassino, 2005), pp. 176-177, 201-203, 210-211

note.value: Description of undertext by Pasquale Orsini

Bibliography: R. L. Bensly, J. R. Harris, and F. C. Burkitt, The Four Gospels in Syriac Transcribed from the Sinaitic Palimpsest (Cambridge, 1894), p. xvi ; Α. S. Lewis, Select Narratives of Holy Women: From the Syro-Antiochene or Sinai palimpsest as written above the old Syriac Gospels by John Stylite, of Beth-mari-qanūn in A.D. 778, I, Syriac text (London, 1900), pp. 45-46 ; A. Hjelt (ed.), Syrus sinaiticus, Helsingfors 1930, p. 15 ; C. Guignard, “0323: A Forgotten 4th or 5th Century Greek Fragment of the Gospel of John in the Syrus Sinaiticus,” Novum Testamentum 57 (2015), pp. 311-319 ; The original quaternion must have been as follows: I (142rv), II (144vr), III (folio lost), IV (folio lost) | V (folio lost), VI (folio lost), VII (147vr), VIII (149rv)
